BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In particular on sunny slopes moist loose snow avalanches are possible. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released by a single winter sport participant.
Artificially triggered avalanches and reports filed by observers confirm poor snowpack stability.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. As a consequence of new snow and wind, deep wind slabs formed. They must be evaluated with care and prudence. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area significant warming.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of snowfall the snowpack could not consolidate.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As the precipitation becomes more intense medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and wet avalanches are to be expected. In particular on wind-loaded slopes dry avalanches can be triggered in the new snow and wind slab layers.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls can be released by a single winter sport participant.
Over a wide area rain to intermediate altitudes. Gradual increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as the snowfall level rises.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2200 m. The moderate wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack. This applies especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In the afternoon in particular at intermediate and high altitudes there will be an increase in the avalanche danger to level 3 (considerable).
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As the snowfall becomes more intense the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent in the afternoon. The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming in particular above approximately 2300 m will become increasingly prone to triggering. Medium-sized to large natural avalanches are possible in particular on very steep slopes.
New snow and wind slabs can be released, even by a single winter sport participant.
Over a wide area rain to intermediate altitudes. Gradual increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as the snowfall level rises.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2200 m. The moderate wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack.
Above approximately 2200 m a lot of snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In the evening as the snowfall becomes more intense there will be an increase in the danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In the afternoon in particular at intermediate and high altitudes there will be an increase in the avalanche danger to level 3 (considerable).
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As the snowfall becomes more intense the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent in the afternoon. The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming in particular above approximately 2300 m will become increasingly prone to triggering. Medium-sized to large natural avalanches are possible in particular on very steep slopes.
New snow and wind slabs can be released, even by a single winter sport participant.
Over a wide area rain to intermediate altitudes. Gradual increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as the snowfall level rises.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2200 m. The moderate wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack.
Above approximately 2200 m a lot of snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In the evening as the snowfall becomes more intense there will be an increase in the danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Above approximately 2000 m snow will fall over a wide area. New snow and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As the precipitation becomes more intense small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized dry and wet avalanches are to be expected.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls can be released by a single winter sport participant.
Over a wide area rain to intermediate altitudes. Gradual increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as the snowfall level rises.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2200 m.
The moderate wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Snowfall at intermediate altitudes. The wind will be moderate to strong. In the course of the day the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. These are to be assessed with care and prudence, especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. These can sometimes be released, even by a single winter sport participant, in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2300 m.
As the precipitation becomes more intense dry and moist avalanches are possible in the evening, but they can reach medium size in isolated cases, especially on very steep slopes, and at the base of rock walls in high Alpine regions.
Danger level 3 (considerable) will be reached in the evening in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow fell on Friday above approximately 2300 m. Several small and medium-sized dry avalanches have been released as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust. Below approximately 2000 m hardly any snow is lying. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow.
Monday: The weather was cold. In some localities 2 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m.
Tuesday: The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow. In some cases the various wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
In some regions snowfall at intermediate altitudes. The weather will be very cloudy.
The snowpack will become in some cases unstable. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation possibly danger level 3 (considerable) will be reached.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Snowfall at intermediate altitudes. The wind will be moderate to strong. In the course of the day the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. These are to be assessed with care and prudence, especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. These can sometimes be released, even by a single winter sport participant, in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2300 m.
As the precipitation becomes more intense dry and moist avalanches are possible in the evening, but they can reach medium size in isolated cases, especially on very steep slopes, and at the base of rock walls in high Alpine regions.
Danger level 3 (considerable) will be reached in the evening in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow fell on Friday above approximately 2300 m. Several small and medium-sized dry avalanches have been released as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust. Below approximately 2000 m hardly any snow is lying. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow.
Monday: The weather was cold. In some localities 2 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m.
Tuesday: The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow. In some cases the various wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
In some regions snowfall at intermediate altitudes. The weather will be very cloudy.
The snowpack will become in some cases unstable. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation possibly danger level 3 (considerable) will be reached.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack necessitate caution. Slight increase in danger of wet and gliding avalanches in the course of the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released in isolated cases by winter sport participants. Caution is to be exercised in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2200 m. Especially shady slopes are unfavourable. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are difficult to recognise.
In addition the mostly small wind slabs adjacent to ridgelines on north facing slopes are capable of being triggered in isolated cases. This applies in particular in high Alpine regions on the Main Alpine Ridge and to the north.

As the day progresses as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be a gradual increase in the danger of wet and gliding avalanches.
Especially on rocky east, south and west facing slopes small to medium-sized wet avalanches are to be expected. This also applies on shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
In addition individual small and medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
At the interface between the old snow surface and the new snow of the past week, occasionally a faceted weak layer developed. This applies above approximately 2200 m.
As a consequence of a sometimes strong southerly foehn wind, mostly small wind slabs will form in the north.
The spring-like weather conditions will give rise to gradual softening of the snowpack especially on sunny slopes. This also applies on shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
The old snowpack will be stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack necessitate caution. Wet loose snow avalanches and gliding avalanches are still possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack necessitate caution. Slight increase in danger of wet and gliding avalanches in the course of the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released in isolated cases by winter sport participants. Caution is to be exercised in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2200 m. Especially shady slopes are unfavourable. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are difficult to recognise.
In addition the mostly small wind slabs adjacent to ridgelines on north facing slopes are capable of being triggered in isolated cases. This applies in particular in high Alpine regions on the Main Alpine Ridge and to the north.

As the day progresses as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be a gradual increase in the danger of wet and gliding avalanches.
Especially on rocky east, south and west facing slopes small to medium-sized wet avalanches are to be expected. This also applies on shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
In addition individual small and medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
At the interface between the old snow surface and the new snow of the past week, occasionally a faceted weak layer developed. This applies above approximately 2200 m.
As a consequence of a sometimes strong southerly foehn wind, mostly small wind slabs will form in the north.
The spring-like weather conditions will give rise to gradual softening of the snowpack especially on sunny slopes. This also applies on shady slopes below approximately 2400 m.
The old snowpack will be stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack necessitate caution. Wet loose snow avalanches and gliding avalanches are still possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Old wind slabs require caution. Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day, especially on very steep sunny slopes.

The wind slabs of recent weeks can be released, especially by large additional loads, above the tree line, caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released in some places especially above approximately 2200 m.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible, caution is to be exercised on steep slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line. The old snowpack is well consolidated. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on an icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack necessitate caution. Wet loose snow avalanches and gliding avalanches are possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In some localities 2 to 5 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday above approximately 1500 m. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. In addition the sometimes new snow-covered wind slabs in the regions exposed to precipitation are capable of being triggered now as before. Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger. In particular on very steep slopes and on wind-loaded slopes small and medium-sized avalanches are possible. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The covering of new snow is soft. Over a wide area new snow is lying on an icy crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sometimes deep wind slabs of the last few days can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Some fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular adjacent to ridgelines as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The solar radiation will give rise from early morning to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack. The meteorological conditions will facilitate a weakening of the snowpack in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in terrain.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of sharply falling temperatures the snowpack will consolidate during the next few days. Some fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects.
